title: French overture
text:
The French overture is a <a href="musical%20form">musical form</a> widely used in the <a href="Baroque%20music">Baroque</a> period. Its basic formal division is into two parts, which are usually enclosed by double bars and repeat signs. They are complementary in style (slow in dotted rhythms and fast in <a href="Fugue">fugal</a> style), and the first ends with a half-cadence (i.e., on a dominant harmony) that requires an answering structure with a tonic ending. The second section often but not always ends with a brief recollection of the first, sometimes even repeating some of its melodic content.
The form is first encountered in <a href="Jean-Baptiste%20Lully">Jean-Baptiste Lully</a>'s ballet overtures from the 1650s. Later examples can be found as the opening movement of each of <a href="Johann%20Sebastian%20Bach">Johann Sebastian Bach</a>'s <a href="Orchestral%20suites%20%28Bach%29">orchestral suites</a>, <a href="Partita%20for%20keyboard%20No.%204%2C%20BWV%20828">Partita in D major, BWV 828</a>, <a href="Cello%20Suites%20%28Bach%29%23Suite%20No.%205%20in%20C%20minor%2C%20BWV%201011">C minor Cello Suite, BWV 1011</a>, and as an opening to many <a href="opera">opera</a>s and <a href="oratorio">oratorio</a>s by <a href="George%20Frideric%20Handel">George Frideric Handel</a> (including "<a href="Messiah%20%28Handel%29">Messiah</a>" and "<a href="Giulio%20Cesare">Giulio Cesare</a>"). The 16th of Bach's "<a href="Goldberg%20Variations">Goldberg Variations</a>" is a miniature French overture.
The French overture should not be confused with the <a href="Italian%20overture">Italian overture</a>, a three-part quick-slow-quick structure.
